The selective oxidation of styrene at its side chains to yield value-added C7 or C8 aromatic compounds represents a crucial reaction within the chemical industry. However, achieving precise control over product formation selectivity poses a significant challenge. In this study, we demonstrate the effectiveness of ultra-small nanosized TiO2-based catalysts in facilitating the selective oxidation of styrene through a mild, eco-friendly photocatalytic approach. Following modification with 0.4% NiO, a notable transformation in product selectivity is observed. The primary products shift from C8 with 96% selectivity to C7 with 92% selectivity under UV, and even sunlight-type excitation. Detailed structural and electronic analyses reveal that the incorporation of NiO onto the TiO2 surface induces the formation of a P-N heterojunction and additional active sites, crucial for promoting C-C cleavage, leading to a selectivity shift from C8 to C7 products. This research provides valuable insights into the design of simple TiO2-based catalysts capable of achieving high selectivity in the oxidation of styrene, highlighting the potential of green photocatalysis in industrial applications. Graphical abstract One-step synthesis of ultra-small nanosized TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 catalysts for selective photocatalytic oxidation of styrene Image, graphical abstract Keywords Styrene Selective oxidation C7 or C8 aromatics P-N heterojunction Green photocatalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The transformation of fundamental chemicals through oxidation into valuable compounds represents a critical process within the chemical industries. Among those reactions, the partial oxidation of readily available and inexpensive styrene gives either C7 aldehyde derivatives, extensively utilized in the chemical industry (flavoring, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and other applications) or to C8 epoxides, which find applications in both chemical and plastic industries. [1] From both environmental and economic viewpoints, hydrogen peroxide or, ideally, molecular oxygen is an ideal oxidant to styrene oxidation with the aid of heterogeneous catalyst [2-7]. The primary challenge associated with utilizing molecular oxygen as an oxidant lies in achieving product selectivity. Conventional catalytic oxidation using O2 under thermal conditions often results in low selectivity due to challenging control over side reactions. Selective oxidations of styrene allow tailored product formation to meet industries requirement for specific chemical structures while minimizing the formation of undesirable by-products. This not only simplifies subsequent purification processes but also improves overall reaction efficiency and economy, positioning selective styrene oxidations as a promising strategy for sustainable and precise chemical transformations. In this context, photo-assisted oxidation processes emerge as promising avenues [8-11]. For example, photoinduced reactions of O2 often yield products that cannot be obtained in dark conditions [12]. Moreover, conducting photochemical reactions at ambient temperature may reduce the likelihood of secondary thermal reactions, thereby enhancing product selectivity[13]. TiO2 present advantages of high reactivity, low price, stable properties, and non-toxicity, has been widely used in photochemical applications such as dye-sensitized solar cells[14], hydrogen production[15] and water treatment technologies[16]. However, the photocatalytic performance of TiO2 faces two primary limitations: the inability to absorb visible light and the swift recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs [17,18]. Consequently, significant research efforts have been focused on enhancing the photocatalytic efficacy of TiO2. [1,19] Studies have shown that doping TiO2 with non-metallic elements like P, N, F, S, C, etc., can extend its light absorption into the visible spectrum[20]. While the introduction of metals (e.g., Ag+, Cu2+, Fe3+, etc.) onto TiO2 can facilitate electron trapping on the surface, thereby impeding electron-hole recombination [21-23]. A novel approach to improving electron-hole separation involves the concept of P-N junctions. By creating an interface between a p-type material (e.g., AgBr, CoO, Cu2O, and NiO) and n-type TiO2, an internal electric field is induced, increasing the likelihood of electron-hole separation and consequently enhancing photocatalytic activity [24]. Additionally, TiO₂-based p-n junctions enhance light absorption and stability, making them highly effective for various photocatalytic applications [25,26]. Despite extensive efforts to enhance the photocatalytic activity of conventional bulk semiconductor TiO2, achieving selectivity in the partial oxidation of styrene remains a formidable challenge. Controlling the reaction presents significant hurdles, often resulting in non-selective photooxidation of styrene to carbon dioxide as the total oxidation product, even at a low conversion. Hence, another imperative is to attain precise control over selectivity to convert styrene into valuable chemical compounds. Several research efforts have been devoted into this compelling topic. For example, Anna Kubacka et. al. proposed addressing the dual objectives of activity and selectivity improvement by surface-sensitizing the TiO2 phase with tungsten [1]. A range of WO3–TiO2 composite catalysts with varying concentrations of tungsten(0.1 W, 0.25 W and 0.5 W) were synthesized. While benzaldehyde is the primary product(over 90% selectivity) with pure TiO2, increasing the tungsten loading enhanced the selectivity towards valuable C7 products(styrene oxide and acetophenone) under both UV and sunlight excitation. However, the improvement in selectivity towards C7 products was limited, increasing from 5.6% over TiO2 to 26.1% over 0.5WO3–TiO2 [1]. Thus, there is still a significant need for substantial efforts to achieve tunable control over the formation of benzaldehyde or oxidized styrene with high activity and selectivity when using TiO2-based catalysts. In this study, we investigate the selective oxidation of styrene using ultra-small nanosized TiO2-based catalysts, both with and without a 0.4% NiO modification, synthesized through a simple one-pot method.(Scheme 1 ) The incorporation of NiO into TiO2 establishes a P-N heterojunction structure, influencing the reaction process and altering the formation of final products. The structural and electronic characterization, and various reaction parameters, were fully investigated to gain a deep understanding of the performance of these two catalysts and the shift in selectivity. In addition, the photocatalytic reaction mechanism for the selective photo-oxidation of styrene with O2 as the oxidant was proposed based on intermediate experiments. 2 Experiments 2.1 Catalysts Synthesis In the NiO/TiO2 synthesis process, tetrabutyl titanate(10 mL) and ethanol(10 mL) are combined in a 100 mL beaker and stirred magnetically for 5 minutes. Subsequently, nickel nitrate hexahydrate(210 mg) is added, and the mixture is stirred thoroughly for uniform distribution. A dropper is then used to add 20 mL of deionized water at a controlled rate of one drop per second. The stirring continues at room temperature for 3 hours before transferring the mixture to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, where it is heated at 150 °C for 12 hours. The obtained solid is washed three times with anhydrous ethanol and deionized water, successively, followed by drying in a 100 °C oven. The dried catalyst undergoes calcination at 400 °C with a nitrogen flow rate of 40 mL/min for 5 hours, resulting in the 0.4% loading NiO/TiO2 catalyst. In the TiO2 synthesis, all steps are identical except for the exclusion of nickel nitrate hexahydrate. 2.2 Characterization methods The morphology of the TiO2-based catalysts was examined using a Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) and High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HR-TEM) on a JEM-2100F electron microscope. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was employed to analyse the crystal structure of catalysts using a Philips X'Pert Pro diffractometer (PW3040/60) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.542 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. The diffraction patterns were recorded over a range of angles from 5 to 80 ° with a scanning rate of 5 ° per minute. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained using a Thermo Fisher XPS spectrometer (Escalab250Xi) using Al Kα radiation. The C1s peak at 284.6 eV served as the reference for calibrating binding energy. The Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) surface area was conducted utilizing N2 adsorption-desorption with a fully automated surface area and pore size analyzer (Autosorb-iQ-2, Quantachrome). Before testing, the sample underwent degassing pretreatment. The post-testing data was analyzed using the BET and Density Functional Theory (DFT) models to determine the surface area of the catalyst. UV–Visible spectra were observed using a UV–Visible-NIR Spectrophotometer (Lambda 750, PerkinElmer) with a spectral range covering 190 to 3300 nm and a resolution of 0.17 nm. All electrochemical assessments of the catalysts were carried out using a Gamry electrochemical workstation, Interface 1010E. The counter electrode utilized a Pt electrode, and the reference electrode employed an Ag/AgCl electrode, with a 0.5 M KOH solution as the electrolyte. The acquired results underwent an adjustment involving the addition of 0.197 V to standardize the electrode potential. In the process of sample preparation, 5 mg of the catalyst underwent dispersion in 2 mL of anhydrous ethanol through ultrasonication for 1.5 h. Following this, the sample was uniformly applied to a Fluorine-doped Tin Oxide (FTO) and left to air-dry, resulting in the formation of a thin catalyst film on the FTO. The FTO coated with the catalyst served as the working electrode for assessing the catalyst's photocurrent and Mott-Schottky characteristics. Photocurrent testing occurred in the dark, with the FTO exposed to a flashlight with a wavelength of 365 nm for 30 s in each cycle. 2.3 Photocatalytic cleavage of styrene The experiments for photocatalytic cleavage of styrene were conducted in a 10 mL Schlenk tube. Typically, 0.2 mmol styrene, along with 3 mL of acetonitrile, and 20 mg of NiO/TiO2 catalyst were added to the tube and sealed. The reactor was subsequently filled with oxygen and exposed to irradiation using light-emitting diodes (LEDs). The resulting products and remaining styrene were subsequently characterized and quantified using gas chromatography-flame ionization detector (GC-FID, Agilent7890). A 1 μL injection volume was used through a 30 m × 530 μm × 0.5 μm column (DB-FFAP) with a split ratio of 20:1. An oven temperature of 40 °C was held for 2 min, followed by a ramp of 7 °C/min to 240 °C, with a subsequent hold for 3 min. The overall run time was 34 min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization The morphology of the TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 catalysts was characterized by TEM and HR-TEM. As can be seen from Fig. 1 a, TiO2 is spherical nanoparticles with a diameter distribution between 4.5–8.5 nm and an average particle size of 6.5 nm. Fig. 1 b is the HR-TEM image of the TiO2 catalyst, and the measured lattice spacing of 3.52 Å corresponds to the (101) plane of anatase TiO2. Fig. 1 c shows the TEM image of the NiO/TiO2 catalyst, which is found to have a spherical nanoparticle morphology with an average particle size of 6.3 nm, similar to that of TiO2. The HR-TEM image of the NiO/TiO2 catalyst shows lattice spacings of 3.52 Å and 2.41 Å, with the former attributed to the (101) plane of anatase TiO2 and the latter attributed to the (101) plane of NiO (Fig. 1 d). In the dark field image of NiO/TiO2, some bright spots were observed on the TiO2 particles, which were identified as NiO particles(Fig. 1 e-f). The particle size distribution of NiO particles was between 1.1–2.1 nm, with an average particle size of 1.5 nm. NiO is a p-type semiconductor, and TiO2 is an n-type semiconductor. This structure of NiO attached to TiO2 forms a p-n heterojunction at the interface between NiO and TiO2[27]. The formation of the heterojunction is beneficial for promoting the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes, increasing the quantum yield, and enhancing the photocatalytic activity of the catalyst[28,29]. The particle size of NiO/TiO2 affects not only the photocatalytic effect of the catalyst, but also its specific surface area. The specific surface area of NiO/TiO2 catalyst was determined by N2 adsorption-desorption experiment, and compared with the reported specific surface area of NiO/TiO2. As can be seen from Table 1 , the BET surface area of the NiO/TiO2 catalyst prepared in this work is as high as 191 m2 g-1, far exceeding that of similar catalysts(15–120 m2 g-1). Previous studies[30,31] have shown that the specific surface area of a catalyst can affect the accessibility of substrates to active sites, thereby influencing the photocatalytic activity of the catalyst. Therefore, the small-sized and large-BET-surface-area NiO/TiO2 prepared in this paper has advantages over currently reported NiO/TiO2. TEM results showed that there was no significant difference in morphology between TiO2 in NiO/TiO2 and pure TiO2. To investigate whether the loading of NiO had an impact on the crystal phase of TiO2, XRD patterns were measured for both NiO/TiO2 and TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 2 a showed that the diffraction peaks of pure TiO2 were located at 25.3, 37.8, 48.0, 55.1, 62.7, 68.8, and 75.0°, which belonged to the (101), (004), (200), (211), (204), (116), and (215) planes of anatase TiO2, respectively[36]. The diffraction peak positions in the XRD pattern of the NiO/TiO2 catalyst were the same as those of pure TiO2, indicating that the presence of NiO did not change the crystal phase of TiO2. Additionally, no diffraction peaks of Ni were observed in the XRD pattern of NiO/TiO2, possibly due to the small size and uniform dispersion of NiO on the surface of TiO2[33]. To further determine whether the presence of NiO alters the valence state of elements in the catalyst, XPS spectra were measured for both pure TiO2 and NiO/TiO2. Fig. 2 d-f show the XPS spectra of Ti, O, and Ni for pure TiO2 and NiO/TiO2, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2 d, the characteristic peaks of Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 for TiO2 are located at 458.95 and 464.71 eV, respectively. The Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2 peaks for NiO/TiO2 are located at 458.28 and 463.78 eV, with a decrease of 0.67 and 0.93 eV, respectively[37,38]. Fig. 2 e shows that the distinct peak of lattice oxygen species in TiO2 appears at 530.13 eV, while the characteristic peak of surface-adsorbed oxygen species is observed at 531.52 eV[39,40]. Similarly, the characteristic peaks of O 1 s in NiO/TiO2 are also shifted to lower binding energy, with the lattice oxygen species peak reduced to 529.43 eV and the surface-adsorbed oxygen species peak reduced to 531.09 eV[41]. Fig. 2 f shows the XPS spectrum of Ni element in NiO/TiO2. The diffraction peaks are located at 855.39, 861.26, 873.12, and 878.89 eV, which correspond to Ni 2p3/2, SAT I, Ni 2p1/2, and SAT II, respectively, representing a typical Ni 2p peak pattern[42]. From the above results, it is evident that compared to TiO2, the binding energy of Ti and O elements in NiO/TiO2 is reduced, indicating that electrons are transferred from Ni to Ti and O elements[43,44]. The shift in binding energies observed in XPS spectra indicates changes in the oxidation states of surface atoms and possibly the formation of surface defects, which can act as active sites for specific reaction pathways. The TEM, XRD, and XPS results showed that the loading of NiO did not alter the physical properties of TiO2 but resulted in changes in the binding energy of Ti and O elements. To investigate the effect of these changes on the band gap of NiO/TiO2, the UV-visible spectra of TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 were measured and the band gap widths of the two catalysts were calculated[45]. From Fig. 2 b, it can be seen that the absorption peak of pure TiO2 is at 415 nm, while the absorption peak of NiO/TiO2 is at 460 nm. This indicates that the absorption edge of the catalyst shifts to the red after loading NiO. Previous research suggests that changes in optical absorption may arise from defect centers formed by substituting Ti4+ ions with doping cations (Ni2+) in the TiO2 crystal lattice. This observation aligns with findings from XPS spectra, indicating the potential formation of surface defects [24,46]. Moreover, the presence of Ni2+ atoms, whether embedded within the bulk TiO2 or situated on its surface sites, induces a rearrangement of neighboring atoms to offset the charge deficiency, consequently leading to lattice deformation [22]. This deformation exerts an influence on the electronic structure, thereby eliciting a shift in the band gap [22]. [47], As depicted in Fig. 2 c, this shift is evident, with the band gaps of TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 calculated to be 2.99 eV and 2.69 eV, respectively, as determined from the UV–vis results. The addition of NiO narrows the band gap of the catalyst, enabling it to utilize a broader range of wavelengths, including visible sunlight (400–700 nm) sources. This change in the band gap allows for more efficient absorption of photons, which can promote specific chemical reactions leading to the formation of desired products. To fully understand the valence band characteristics of the catalysts, it is crucial to evaluate the conduction band as well. Mott-Schottky testing can be employed to calculate the conduction band of semiconductors. In Fig. 2 g, the Mott-Schottky curve of TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 is depicted, where the use of an Ag/AgCl electrode requires an additional 0.197 V to be added to the obtained potential. As illustrated in the figure, the conduction band of TiO2 is -0.44 eV, while that of NiO/TiO2 is -0.38 eV. Based on the conduction band and band gap, the valence band of TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 were calculated to be 2.55 and 2.31 eV, respectively. Subsequently, band structure diagrams for TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 catalysts are depicted based on their valence band, conduction band, and band gap (Fig. 2 h). The photoelectric effects of photocatalysts play a crucial role, with photocurrent density serving as a key indicator of their photocatalytic activity[48,49]. As shown in Fig. 2 i, both TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 exhibit the generation of photocurrent during illumination, with a rapid decline observed after turning off the light. The photocurrent density of TiO2 is approximately 0.7 μA/cm2, while the photocurrent density of NiO/TiO2 is four times higher than that of TiO2, reaching approximately 2.8 μA/cm2. This signifies that the incorporation of NiO effectively enhances the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes, elevates the quantum yield of the catalyst, and augments its overall photocatalytic activity [49,50]. 3.2 Catalytic reactions The selective photocatalytic oxidation of styrene was examined under LED lamp irradiation at 365 nm in acetonitrile solvent as a model reaction, with corresponding conversion and selectivity data outlined in Table 2 . Four primary products were identified: benzaldehyde(a) and benzoic acid(b), formed after the C=C bond cleavage, categorized as C7 products, whereas oxidized styrene(c) and acetophenone(d), generated without C=C bond breakage, were classified as C8 products. Blank experiments indicated that the catalyst, O2, and light all played pivotal roles, as evidenced by almost no conversion observed after 12 hours without any of them (Table 2 , entries 1–3). Using pure TiO2 as a catalyst yielded a styrene conversion of 93%, with a 12% selectivity to C7 products and an 82% selectivity to C8 products (Table 2 , entry 4). While employing NiO/TiO2 as a catalyst shifted the primary product from C8 to C7, resulting in a 74% selectivity to C7 products (Table 2 , entry 5). Notably, NiO/TiO2 exhibited robust photocatalytic activity even under visible light excitation, achieving a styrene conversion of 95% and a C7 product selectivity of 83% at a wavelength of 420 nm when the reaction time was extended to 30 hours (Table 2 , entry 6). This observation is consistent with its UV–vis results. Subsequently, TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 catalysts were employed under varied wavelengths and reaction times to assess their impact on product selectivity(Figs. 3 ). Optimal results with TiO2 as a catalyst were observed at a wavelength of 365 nm, achieving a styrene conversion of 93%, a C7 product yield of 11%, and a C8 product yield of 82%. However, with an increase in wavelength to 380 nm, the conversion dropped to 56%, with a C7 product yield of 37% and a C8 product yield of 19%. Further elevation of the wavelength to 420 nm resulted in a styrene conversion of only 7%. When employing NiO/TiO2 as a catalyst, the conversion of styrene at a 365 nm wavelength is 97%, with the main product C7 yielding 72%, and the C8 product yielding 25%. With an increase in wavelength, the styrene conversion shows a decreasing trend. However, at a wavelength of 420 nm, the styrene conversion rises to 40%, which is much higher than that of using TiO2 catalyst. This suggests superior photocatalytic activity of NiO/TiO2 in the visible light spectrum compared to TiO2, consistent with band gap measurement results. The experimental results demonstrate that both TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 catalysts exhibit optimal performance at a wavelength of 365 nm. Consequently, the styrene conversion and product yield were investigated at reaction times of 6 h, 12 h, 18 h, and 24 h under a 365 nm wavelength. When employing the TiO2 catalyst for 6 hours, the styrene achieved a 34% conversion, with a 9% yield of C7 product and a 25% yield of C8 product. Extending the reaction time to 12 hours significantly increased the conversion to 93%, and further extension to 18 hours resulted in near-complete conversion (99%), with 4% selectivity to C7 products and 96% selectivity to C8 products. Using NiO/TiO2 as a catalyst for a 6-hour reaction yielded a relatively low styrene conversion of 38%, with C7 and C8 product yields of 30% and 8%, respectively. At 12 hours, the conversion significantly increased to 97%, and further extension to 18 hours led to a conversion of 99%, with C7 and C8 selectivity of 80% and 20%, respectively. After 24 hours, complete styrene conversion was achieved, with C7 and C8 selectivity remaining similar to those at 18 hours. These findings reveal that the styrene achieves a conversion surpassing 90% after 12 hours of reaction with both TiO2 and NiO/TiO2 catalysts. Further prolonging the reaction time to 18 and 24 hours has minimal impact on the styrene conversion and does not alter the selectivity of the product. Prior research has shown that the choice of solvent can influence the product selectivity in photocatalytic reactions[51-54]. To delve into this impact, acetone and ethyl acetate were selected as reaction solvents, replacing acetonitrile. The reactions were carried out at a wavelength of 365 nm for 12 h, and the results are shown in Fig. 4 . When employing TiO2 as the catalyst with acetone as the reaction solvent, the styrene achieved a 99% conversion, accompanied by 72% selectivity to C7 products and 28% selectivity to C8 products. Similarly, using ethyl acetate as the reaction solvent resulted in a 99% conversion of styrene, with C7 and C8 selectivity of 63% and 37%, respectively. These outcomes underscore that, in comparison to acetonitrile, the use of acetone and ethyl acetate as reaction solvents significantly enhances the oxidation and cleavage of C=C bonds in styrene, effectively promoting the generation of C7 products. When employing NiO/TiO2 as the catalyst with either acetone or ethyl acetate as the reaction solvent, the primary product remains C7 products(Fig. 4 b). In both acetone and ethyl acetate solvents, the conversion of styrene reaches 99%. Specifically, with acetone as the reaction solvent, the selectivity to C7 and C8 products is 92% and 8%, respectively. Alternatively, when ethyl acetate is the reaction solvent, the selectivity to C7 and C8 products is 90% and 10%, respectively. Under consistent wavelength and reaction time conditions, both the conversion of styrene and the selectivity to C7 products increased when acetone and ethyl acetate were employed as reaction solvents. This further suggests that acetone and ethyl acetate solvents facilitate the photocatalytic oxidation of styrene by breaking the C=C bond to generate C7 products. To assess the recyclability of NiO/TiO2 catalyst, a recycling experiment was conducted using ethyl acetate as the reaction solvent at a wavelength of 365 nm for 12 hours. Repeat experiments using NiO/TiO2 are shown in Fig. 5 . Remarkably, the catalytic performance remained consistently high even after the fifth run, achieving a conversion of 97%, with corresponding selectivity of 89% for C7 and 11% for C8 products—results very close to those of the initial run. Additionally, TEM images show that the structure of the catalyst remained unchanged (Figure S2). Combining photocurrent testing (Fig. 2 i) and catalyst recycling experiment, it can be concluded that NiO/TiO2 has good photocatalytic stability and recyclability. 3.3 Reaction mechanism study In order to investigate the products formation route, photocatalytic oxidation experiments were conducted using oxidized styrene and acetophenone as reaction substrates in acetonitrile solvent for 12 hours at a wavelength of 365 nm. The findings from these experiments are presented in Table 3 . When using styrene oxide as the substrate and NiO/TiO2 as the catalyst, the conversion of styrene oxide is 56%, the yields of acetophenone, benzaldehyde, and benzoic acid are 9%, 18%, and 29%, respectively. When TiO2 is used as a catalyst, the conversion of styrene is 24%, and only acetophenone and benzaldehyde are generated. This further proves that the photocatalytic activity of NiO/TiO2 is stronger than that of TiO2. Moreover, neither NiO/TiO2 nor TiO2 can cause further reaction of acetophenone(Table 3, b and d). This indicates that in the process of photocatalytic oxidation of styrene, the first step is to form oxidized styrene, which then further reacts to produce acetophenone or benzaldehyde and benzoic acid. [55,56]. In order to confirm whether the reaction goes through radical pathway, we conducted a radical inhibition experiment using benzoquinone, a typical O₂•⁻ radical scavenger, as a trapping agent [1]. When 100 mg of benzoquinone was added to the reaction system, the yields of products a and c significantly decreased from 35% and 20% to 9.3% and 0.2%, respectively, while the yields of products b and d dropped to 0% (see Table S1). This result indicates that benzoquinone effectively quenched the reaction, suggesting that O₂•⁻ radicals play a crucial role in promoting the oxidation process. Additionally, we have conducted in situ EPR experiments to confirm the presence of superoxide radicals during the reaction, using 5,5-dimethyl-1- pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) as a trapping agent. The results revealed the appearance of sextet peaks corresponding to the DMPO-O₂•⁻ adduct over NiO/TiO₂, compared to the absence of the catalyst(see Fig. 6 ). This indicates that O₂•⁻ radicals are the reactive oxygen species responsible for styrene oxidation, consistent with the results of the radical inhibition experiment. Combining the experimental findings and relevant research [56-58], a plausible mechanism for the photocatalytic oxidation of styrene over NiO/TiO2, as depicted in Scheme 2 . Initially, the NiO/TiO2 catalyst generates photo-generated electrons and photo-generated holes under illumination. Styrene undergoes oxidation by photo-generated holes, leading to the formation of cationic radicals as transition states[59]. Subsequently, O2 combines with photo-generated electrons to form ·O2 - [60]. The interaction between the cationic free radicals of styrene and ·O2 - promotes the formation of oxidized styrene and acetophenone[61]. Further, oxidized styrene undergoes cleavage of C-C bond, yielding benzaldehyde and benzoic acid, as confirmed by our intermediate experiment. 4 Conclusion In summary, this study demonstrates the effectiveness of ultra-small nanosized TiO2-based catalysts in finely tuning the catalytic selectivity in styrene photocatalytic oxidation through a mild and environmentally friendly process. Under optimal conditions, both pure TiO2 and 0.4% NiO/TiO2 catalysts enable the selective oxidation of styrene, achieving near-complete conversion. Specifically, the pure TiO2 catalyst yields 96% selectivity towards C8 in acetonitrile solvent after 18 hours, while the 0.4% NiO-modified TiO2 catalyst exhibits 92% selectivity towards C7 in acetone solvent after 12 hours. Thorough characterization and electrochemical evaluations reveal that the inclusion of NiO forms a p-n heterojunction, reduces the band gap of the catalyst, enabling effective utilization of visible light, and generates additional active sites. These factors play a crucial role in promoting C-C cleavage, leading to a selectivity shift from C8 to C7 products. This study highlights the potential for controlling products formation by designing photocatalysts with different structures and creating additional active sites. coredata.dc:description: The selective oxidation of styrene at its side chains to yield value-added C7 or C8 aromatic compounds represents a crucial reaction within the chemical industry. However, achieving precise control over product formation selectivity poses a significant challenge. In this study, we demonstrate the effectiveness of ultra-small nanosized TiO2-based catalysts in facilitating the selective oxidation of styrene through a mild, eco-friendly photocatalytic approach. Following modification with 0.4% NiO, a notable transformation in product selectivity is observed. The primary products shift from C8 with 96% selectivity to C7 with 92% selectivity under UV, and even sunlight-type excitation. Detailed structural and electronic analyses reveal that the incorporation of NiO onto the TiO2 surface induces the formation of a P-N heterojunction and additional active sites, crucial for promoting C-C cleavage, leading to a selectivity shift from C8 to C7 products. This research provides valuable insights into the design of simple TiO2-based catalysts capable of achieving high selectivity in the oxidation of styrene, highlighting the potential of green photocatalysis in industrial applications.
